text: hey guys thomas joseph here and today we
are talking about pumpkin bread now have
you ever had this happen to you where
you go to the effort of making a
delicious pumpkin bread and it ends up
sunken and gummy like this version is
here you can see that bottom layer of
really wet batter that still like stays
in the final bakes good well today i'm
gonna share with you some tricks and
tips and actually a fantastic recipe for
pumpkin bread that i'm sure you will be
making in this season we're gonna get
started with me main ingredient and that
is pumpkin now here in the test kitchens
of Martha Stewart Living we kind of shy
away from a lot of prepared foods or
canned foods but other than beans
pumpkin is one of the great canned food
items that's really really consistent
and that's kind of key whatever you're
baking in general and especially in the
fall when pumpkin is so popular than
somebody baked goods so this consistent
texture and flavor of pumpkin is really
key so I'm using one 15 ounce can of
pumpkin puree this isn't flavored with
pumpkin pie spice you guys cuz we're
gonna be adding our own spices to this
batter but again having this consistent
pumpkin is really kind of key in making
a loaf that will turn out really well
and not gummy and sunken and to this I'm
gonna add sugar I have a cup of
granulated sugar and a cup of dark brown
sugar and this is packed brown sugar and
this is going right into my stand mixer
here and I'm gonna just mix this
together until it's nice and evenly
combined now the reason we're using two
different sugars is one for flavor and
also for texture now brown sugar whether
it's light or dark has a good amount of
molasses in it and that
this creates a shoe or more texture to
it and then granulated sugar and that's
really great in a pumpkin bread because
you want something that has a good
amount of structure slice ability so I'm
gonna mix these up and while I'm doing
this I'm gonna bring together my dry
ingredients so here I have three and a
quarter cups of all-purpose flour I'm
not using self-rising flour or cake
flour just regular all-purpose and to
this I'm gonna add three quarters of a
teaspoon of coarse salt a little bit of
spice because as always with pumpkin
breads you need to kind of amp up the
flavor or make it even more a tumble by
adding some of the warm spices and so I
have two teaspoons of ground cinnamon a
half a teaspoon of freshly grated nutmeg
and nutmeg is kind of one of the spices
that I like to have on hand whole and I
like to grate it as needed because I
feel like you get really great fresh
flavor so that looks good there and now
a quarter of a teaspoon of ground
allspice now if you didn't have allspice
or you weren't a fan you could certainly
substitute this for something else
ground ginger would be fantastic in here
as well any warm autumnal spice would be
fantastic now I'm just gonna whisk these
spices together and then the last two
dry ingredients that I'm gonna add to
this mix are the leavening agents and
I'm using two different leavening agents
today baking powder three teaspoons and
baking powder is typically sold as
double acting baking powder meaning that
it reacts at two different stages in the
process of baking so the first would be
when you introduce a liquid it reacts
and creates bubbles which create Lebanon
and then also with heat now I'm also
using a baking soda and 1/2 teaspoon of
baking soda here and the baking soda is
actually going to react with the acidic
in the pumpkin bread and the primary
aesthetic component is going to be added
in at the end and that is buttermilk so
that again is going to create little
bubbles little gases which will help to
leaven the bread so just mix all of this
together and you want to make sure that
you do this with a wire whisk and do it
for a few seconds just to evenly
incorporate all of the spices and the
leavening with the flour and then I'm
just gonna set this off to the side and
I'm gonna add the rest of my wet
ingredients to my mixer here so the eggs
to this mix now speaking a little bit
more about the gummy factor in a spice
loaf like this you'd want to make sure
that you don't have an excessive amount
of moisture so you're getting a lot of
moisture from the eggs the buttermilk
the butter and the pumpkin itself so you
have to make sure that the batter is
evened out with enough leavening and
also enough flour so this is a really
great recipe guys and I would encourage
you to follow it but you can certainly
play up with those spices and make it
your own so four whole eggs and add
these to your mixer one at a time and
whenever you guys are baking cakes
cupcakes muffins or these quick breads
you want to make sure that your
ingredients are all at room temperature
so that you have a batter ultimately
that is evenly incorporated you'll get a
much better rise out of the batter when
it goes in the oven and ultimately a
better texture so I'm adding the eggs
one at a time here and I'm going to add
the fat which is one and a half sticks
of unsalted butter that I've melted and
cooled now oftentimes you'll see quick
bread recipes or spice cakes that are
made with oil and that oil that fat
gives the cake or the loaf moisture so
it keeps the cake nice and moist and it
will actually last for a few days which
is really great I'm using melted butter
here because I want the flavor of butter
and if everything is at room temperature
again guys your batter shouldn't be
broken at all and it looks nice and
smooth here you don't see any curdled
bits and that's because everything's at
room temperature so this looks good and
now I'm going to add the dry ingredients
I'm just gonna just dump this right in
the side here
and I'm also gonna add the buttermilk
and this is a half a cup of buttermilk
so not too too much again the more
liquid that goes into this batter the
risk of it being gummy in the end so
just mix this now until the batter comes
together you don't want to over mix this
because you will toughen your loaf that
will get too too chewy so just until
this all comes together and while this
does pre-heat your oven you guys to 350
degrees and we'll make sure that you
have to loaf pans that are prepared
there about nine by five inch loaf pans
that have been buttered and I've
prepared them with some parchment paper
that has extended over the sides and
this will help us get the loaves out of
the container once they've cooled
slightly now I'm going to remove this
paddle attachment here give the bowl a
little bit of a scrape so that
everything is evenly incorporated and
you want to divide this batter up
between your loaf pans you could
certainly use a digital scale to weigh
out the batter to get to nice even loafs
so now these go right into that 350
degree oven for about 40 to 45 minutes
test with a cake tester or a toothpick
in the center of the loaf with a few
crumbs that's totally fine but you want
it to be mostly cleaned again 40 to 45
minutes so our pumpkin loaf has been out
of the oven now when it comes out of the
oven you want to let it rest in the pan
for about 10 minutes and then you want
to invert it onto a wire rack to cool
completely you want to make sure that
you get it out of the pan so that it
doesn't steam too much if it steams it
will likely create a gummy layer on the
bottom of the bread also the bottom
crust here it won't be crusty it'll be
soft and a little soggy so I just want
to show you guys what this looks like
inside guys this is the perfect recipe
for pumpkin bread I encourage you to
